question: Airight so this is the world and there are five billion people on it. When I was a kid there were three. It's hard to keep up. That's better. That's america. See, America still sets the tone for the world... In Indiana -- Clark Hodd. 13. The best point guard in the country. Puberty hasn't been easy. Becky Farling. You'll see her in the next Olympics. Seattle, Washington. Dallas Malloy. Went to court to be allowed to box professionally. She's 16. Art Stallings, Indio, California. Check out what pure joy looks like. In Odessa, Texas, the great Frank Cushman. Cush is 20. Quarterback, role model, my client. He'll probably go number one in the draft this year. There's genius everywhere, but until they turn pro, it's like popcorn in the pan. Some pop... ... some don't. Now I'm the guy you don't usually see. I'm the one behind the scenes. I'm the sports agent.
answer: Easy now, we can spread these numbers over five years...

question: You know those photos where the new player holds up the team jersey and poses with the owner? That's me on the left. Inside that building, that's where I work. Sports Management International. Thirty-three out of shape agents guiding the careers of 2,120 of the most finely-tuned athletes alive... ... in this economy, sometimes emotions run a little high.
answer: Listen, there's no proof of anything except that this guy is a sensational athlete.

question: Lately, it's gotten worse.
answer: Yes! Come on -- it'd take a tank to stop your dad. It would take all five Super Trooper VR Warriors, right?

question: Two nights later in Miami at our corporate conference, a breakthrough. Breakdown? Breakthrough. It was the oddest, most unexpected thing. I began writing what they call a Mission Statement for my company. You know -- a Mission Statement -- a suggestion for the future. What started out as one page became twenty-five. Suddenly I was my father's son. I was remembering the simple pleasures of this job, how I ended up here out of law school, the way a stadium sounds when one of my players performs well on the field... I was remembering even the words of the late Dicky Fox, the original sports agent, who said: And suddenly it was all pretty clear. The answer was fewer clients. Caring for them, caring for ourselves, and the games too. Starting our lives, really. Hey, I'll be the first to admit it. What I was writing was somewhat "touchy feely." I didn't care. I had lost the ability to bullshit. It was the me I'd always wanted to be. I printed it up in the middle of the night, before I could re-think it.
answer: Thanks. Hi, it's jerry maguire. Uh, listen did those manuscripts get... Oh they did... No no no no no, that's fine... Jerry in suit, alone with his luggage. Dry throat. clammy, holds onto the handrail to steady himself.

question: You're with the sports people on the plane, right?
answer: Jerry Maguire. SMI.

question: Bobbi Fallon. BPI. I'm producing the Coke commercials for the playoffs.
answer: Well. Good luck with that --

question: Can I just get a quick "man's" opinion from you on something? And I can't say his name without laughing I want to eat him up. I want to say goodbye to every bad thought I ever had about relationships. I mean, I crave this guy... and yet... why... why did I have that affair this weekend? Does that mean I'm not in love with my boyfriend?
answer: I think you'll know when you see him at the gate.

question: It's the death rattle of my singlehood, right? Because I finally see the white picket fence looming and I love it/hate it/love it/hate it/ love it... you're right, I'll know when I see him. Why is it so easy to talk with you?! Tell me about your fiancee.
answer: I uh... don't think we're quite at your pitch yet.

question: Tell me, and then you can sleep.
answer: She's an NFL publicist... amazing sense of style... former athlete... volleyball... world class... really knows how to live every moment of her life, which is why I should take a nap now... No no...

question: Oh, tell the story.
answer: --so our first date, she told me about her favorite place in the world, the seven pools of Hana on the island of Maui...

question: Gorgeous.
answer: A year-and-a-half later, we were both in Hawaii for the Pro Bowl. Now I've always hit a wall at 18 months. Every serious girlfriend lasts 18 months. It's like --ka- boom. The curse of 18 months.

question: That's when you need to cement, and define define define.
answer: Exactly. And the world does not need another 35 year-old bachelor. I knew I wanted to propose, so I took her there.

question: To the pools?
answer: To the pools. Now she's Miss Rock Climber, and I'm more the Non-Rock Climber, but we're hiking up through the pools and there's a fine mist in the air, and I have the ring in my pocket, and I'm a little nervous, I'm lagging behind, and she says to me, get this -- "Hurry up, klutz."

question: Oh no --
answer: Well, it bothered me somewhat. And I got quiet. And now she's quiet and we're both pouting a little, you know. And I decide I'm not going to propose. The mood is not right. Why be impulsive? Now at this point I know she knows that I was going to propose and didn't. And she knows I know. So the entire sixty mile ride back to the airport, we don't speak. And we're both good at that. We fly to Honolulu in silence. We check into the Pro Bowl hotel --

question: How sad --
answer: But wait...

question: Ray! Ray!
answer: Can I help?

question: Oh. Hi. I work in your office. I was on the junket to the conference. I'm --
answer: I know who y6u are. You're Dorothy Boyd. You're in... wait... you're in Accounts. You have the middle cubicle toward the back with that poster of Albert Einstein morphed onto Shaquille 0 Neal's body.

question: Hmm. Pretty good.
answer: Now what did you lose?

question: My son... my mind...
answer: Well, while I go look for him, why don't you hang onto this curious gentleman behind you --

question: Remember "imagination?"... remember what that means? Well, this is one of my bosses so you will now IMAGINE me screaming at you right now. Do NOT do that again. Ever ever EVER. Well, thanks.
answer: Well, take care.

question: And have fun at your bachelor party. Oh no.
answer: No no. I knew.

question: Nnnnn. I just killed the surprise.
answer: No, I'm just... anxiously looking past it. I already had my bachelor party. It was called "my twenties." See you later.

question: I loved your memo, by the way.
answer: Thanks... actually, it was just a "Mission Statement."

question: I think in this age, optimism like that... it's a revolutionary act.
answer: You think so?

question: Oh tsht. Yes.
answer: I appreciate that, because some of that stuff... you know, it was two in the morning and...

question: Don't ever stop fucking me!
answer: Sooner... or later... I'll have to stop.

question: Oh Gawd, oh yes, it's never been better. Never BETTER!! Never BETTER!! Open your eyes. If you ever want me to be with another woman for you, I would do it. I'm not interested in it. There was a time, yes, it felt normal for me, but it was a phase, a college thing, like torn Levi's or law school for you... people change, but if you ever feel like being adventurous in that way, I would do it for you. You want anything from the kitchen I'm going to get some fruit --
answer: You know. I don't think we need to do the thing where we tell each other everything!

question: Jerry, this is what intimacy is! Who told you?
answer: One of the accountants.

question: Now I don't know what you do for your five-percent, but this man, my husband has a whole plan, an image... we majored in marketing, Jerry, and when you put him in a Waterbed Warehouse commercial, excuse me, you are making him common. He is pure gold and you're giving him "Waterbed Warehouse" when he deserves the big four -- shoe, car, clothing- line, soft-drink. The four jewels of the celebrity endorsement dollar. You gonna get that --
answer: Not a chance. Marcee, things are changing around here. You and Rod will have my total personal attention.

question: Damn right, and you can start by taking Rod's poster and putting it where people can see it!
answer: Damn right.

question: Look at that handsome man, trying to build a life up there by the air-conditioner. We're coming to get ya, darlin! We are so close to having it all!
answer: Gimme a second here... Tidwell... Arizona contract... new glass cabinet...

question: Gimme a second here... Tidwell... Arizona contract... new glass cabinet...
answer: You okay?

question: I'm fine. What's up?
answer: I came here to let you go.

question: Pardon me?
answer: Came here to fire you, Jerry. It's real, Jerry. You... you should say something.

question: Aw shit...the crowded restaurant... so there's no scene...
answer: I know. It sucks. I suck.

question: You...
answer: You did this to yourself. You said "fewer clients." You put it all on paper. Scully was very upset. Heart attacks make some people sweeter, but not him. You did this to yourself -- -- although I do gotta hand it to you. For about five minutes you had everyone applauding smaller revenues.

question: You... ungrateful... unctuous...
answer: ... dick?

question: Dick.
answer: Give me a little credit for doing this face-to-face! What I went through knowing I was going to do this to my mentor! Can you get past yourself for a second?

question: You'll lose.
answer: You wanted smaller.

question: I'm over it. Now I want all my clients and yours too.
answer: Jerry --

question: -- and I'll get 'em.
answer: You'll always be my hero, Jerry. Always always always. We're bringing other elements in, we're focusing on endorsements -- it's not about handholding anymore. We're no longer babysitters --

question: Alright, we're just getting started on my list of things you need to know. Take notes if you want to.
answer: Okay.

question: Good, 'cause see, I am a valuable commodity. I go across the middle. I see the ball and a dude coming right at me, wanting to kill me, I tell my brain "get killed, catch the ball." That's New York Steak, baby. Rare. And yet, nobody's giving me LOVE. Nobody's giving me PROPS. Nobody. I went to Arizona State, I'm from Arizona, I break Arizona records, I'm a Sun Devil, man!!!
answer: Now you want Arizona dollars.

question: -- now to recap, I want to stay in Arizona, I want my new contract, I like you, you're nice to my wife, I will stay with you, that's what I'm doing for you, but here's what you're gonna do for me. You listening?

question: It's a very personal, very important thing. It's a family motto. So I want to share it with you. You ready?
answer: Yes.

question: Here it is. "Show me the money." Show. Me. The. Money.
answer: I got it.

question: Now doesn't that just make you feel good to say it? Say it with me.
answer: Show. Me. The. Money.

question: Dorothy Boyd! Thank you! We will see you all again. Sleep tight! Let's see how they do without us. Wonder what he said.
answer: My favorite aunt is hearing impaired. He said "you complete me." So I know this is a bad time, but -- you will have a medical program, right?

question: Sure. Yes. Medical, I don't know.
answer: And I guess we didn't talk about money. So, I'll just dive in --

question: Give me your number. I'll call tomorrow. I'm just a little. I'm a little insane right now. But it's going to be great.
answer: No no, I know --

question: But I mean really... wonderfully... great.
answer: Absolutely.

question: And when you think about what you've done later, don't panic.
answer: Me? No. My sister -- it's a good bet. That took guts.

question: What about medical?
answer: Of course, medical!

question: You are a single mother. You have given up the right to be frivolous.
answer: If you'd read what he wrote, you would have left with him too.

question: You know how much those Well Child exams cost --
answer: Of course I know --

question: And that's just when he's well --
answer: Wait. Where is he?

question: He's in the living room asleep.
answer: Wonderful. Next time you lecture me, don't leave my little boy in a room with your Divorced Women's Group...

question: The power move is to go unannounced. Black suit, right?
answer: And the egyptian cotton shirt that works with or without the jacket. Tell me again, how was it left with Cush?

question: "Dad says we gwan sleep on it.
answer: Ugh!

question: Seventy-two clients. ONE stayed. Jacket on, tie in pocket.
answer: Good. They're all heatseekers! All of them, everybody. You keep one superstar and they'll all follow. There's no real loyalty, and the first person who told me that, Jerry Maguire, was you.

question: I think I was trying to sleep with you at the time.
answer: Well, it worked, and I will not let you fail. You are Jerry Ma- fuckin-guire.

question: That's right.
answer: King of the Housecalls! Master of the Living Room!

question: Okay, this is working.
answer: You are not a loser.

question: Who said anything about "loser?" Where do you get this word "loser?"
answer: I'm sorry. I was on a roll. I meant something else. When do you want to leave?

question: Now.
answer: Let's go. I'll drive you.

question: What if I don't get him?
answer: Function function function. Forward motion is everything. Cush saves all.

question: You like a Bloody Beer, Jerry? Beer and tomato juice --
answer: No thanks. Matt, I came here because in all honesty your son is just another piece of cattle to SMI. But to me --

question: We decided to stay with you.
answer: Oh, thank you.

question: Told myself -- if he shows up, we'll stick with him.
answer: You know, I'm not a hugger and yet... I can't let go.

question: Honey -- later, okay? Whoop. Wait.
answer: Hello?

question: Wait. That's yesterday, from the other office. Today is... ... light.
answer: Shit, it's just so frustrating to not be able to talk to Avery --

question: Dorothy, let me tell you something, we are back. We are so very very back. I re-signed Cush. We're set.
answer: We are?

question: It's all going to work.
answer: I just got goosebumps.

question: It's all going to work. We're going to save the world.
answer: Well, I'm happy for you.

question: Happy for us.
answer: Happy for us... okay. Here's the number. 404-453-2222.

question: Thanks.
answer: Call me later, hon. Wait. Did I just say "hon" to him?

question: Avery, I signed Cush. Again.
answer: YA-HOOOO-SIE!

question: I know. Sorry I threw a scare into our lives there --
answer: Don't worry about it -- I never told you what I thought of that memo either --

question: Well, no you didn't --
answer: You lost your head, it happens. I'm so fuckin jazzed! Listen. I'm going to have to fly to Chicago tomorrow, how 'bout if we meet in the Dallas airport and we all fly into New York together for the draft?

question: It's a plan -- --
answer: I'll set it up with your girl. Woo! This is when it's good, Jerry. Enjoy it. Live it. Love it. And when I see you, I'm going to give you the best blow job of your life.

question: Hey man, I wish I had a quarterback like you in Arizona. You're the shit.
answer: Thank ya.

question: Well you ain't that mothafuckin good.
answer: Say what?

question: Heard that.
answer: At last I find you.

question: Why the fuck am I here? I feel like I'm five years late for the Prom.
answer: Come on. Come with me. We're going to take a walk through this lobby. I want every media guy, every player rep, everybody to see you for what you are. The best- kept secret in the NFL. The biggest wide-receiver in the game. Let 'em see ya, Rod. And Whatever you do, don't sit down. Let 'em see how big you are. You ready? Let's do it.

question: A'right. Let's walk. I came all the way here for that? To walk the lobby?
answer: Yeah. And it might have even worked too.

question: Let's do it again. You believe they're shooting a Nike ad down there? Did I ever tell you my Nike story?
answer: I gotta get back to Cushman.

question: Okay, I understand. I'll boil it down for ya. Fuck Nike. All they do is ignore me...
answer: You know what was great about you down there? For about five minutes, you unloaded that rather expansive, let me just say "large" chip that resides right there on your shoulder, and you know what? You were brilliant. Take care.

question: You're loving me now, aren't ya?
answer: I'm not about love -- I'm about "showing you the money."

question: Good. I was just testing ya. But just you saying that? Makes me love ya.
answer: Get some sleep. See you tomorrow.

question: Sure you don't want to go out and find some karoake? I'm a very good singer, man --

question: Hey, what size are you? Why don't you grab a couple pairs of them new Nikes by the door -- God, you're like a dude.

question: "It's okay to eat fish, 'cause they Don't have any feelings...
answer: Okay. San Diego just came in with a last-minute scenario. It's big.

question: Look, before I go back to Denver. I think we should put something down on paper. Something that says, "hey, I'm with Jerry Maguire."

question: Do I know everything there is to know here? You fellas aren't talking with Bob Sugar, are you?

question: Said who? Sugar?

question: So you empowered Bob Sugar to deal with Denver behind my back?

question: Well. Okay. Of course. You're twenty years old, and I'm just another guy in a suit. It's all business. It didn't work out. You didn't buy my product, which is, unfortunately, mm. answer: I just heard.

question: What do I do? How do I spin this?

question: What did I do to you?
answer: It's all about you, isn't it? Soothe me, save me, love me --

question: Could you just stop moving?
answer: I have to finish my job --

question: Everything's on the fucking run! Everything --
answer: Jerry. You and I are salespeople. We sell --

question: Look, I don't want a --

question: Go ahead. Jump right on into my nightmare. The water's warm.

question: Tell you what -- I'd prefer loyalty..

question: I think you added the "brutal."
answer: Jerry, there is a "sensitivity" thing that some people have. I don't have it. I don't cry at movies. I don't gush over babies. I don't start celebrating Christmas five months early, and I don't tell a man who just screwed up both of our lives -- 'oh, poor baby.' That's me. For better or worse. But I do love you.

answer: Don't say it. We're both ragged out right now.

question: -- stop --

question: It's over --

question: There is something missing here.

answer: Oh Jerry.

question: You know I didn't ever want to hurt you.

question: Everybody on this show cries now.

I don't really need it, because I'm CLOAKED IN FAILURE. I lost the number one draft pick the night before the draft. They will teach my story to other agents on "do not do this" day in agent school. question: You are not allowed to act this way.

answer: Hey you.

question: Well.

question: Good evening.

question: Forget it. Forget it.
answer: No tell me.
